Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: Extending phylogenetic comparative methods for evaluating within-species trends in a macroevolutionary context
Award.AbstractNarration:
How do evolutionary changes within species translate into broad patterns across a group of related species? This question is at the heart of evolutionary ecology, but has been very difficult to answer. A major problem is that current analytical approaches, known as phylogenetic comparative methods, require that a single value be used to represent a trait for an entire species. As a result, valuable information on differences among individuals within a species can't be used. This limits the types of questions that these comparative methods can address. The main goal of this project is to develop new analytical software that accounts for trait variation within species, which will result in a much more powerful computational tool. The newly developed software will be tested using experimental data from salamanders and fish. This award will have multiple broader impacts. This new tool will let a whole new set of hypotheses be tested and will be widely used by scientists doing evolutionary ecology research. Undergraduate students will receive hands-on training in mathematical modeling and software development. Educational outreach activities include a research-education exchange between a regional undergraduate university and a large research university. National and international teaching workshops will help train the next generation of students and scientists from around the world.

Analyses of phenotypic data tend to remain distinctly different enterprises between microevolutionary and macroevolutionary studies. Consequently, we still do not know how microevolutionary trends from ecological selection associate to macroevolutionary trends across phylogenies. Phylogenetic comparative methods (PCMs) measure the amount of phylogenetic signal in a set of data or account for the phylogenetic relatedness among observations when evaluating ecological variation, but currently work only with single values for species. Thus, large amounts of within-species data are disregarded when using PCMs, which limits their inferential capability. This project will develop an analytical solution to this problem, and provide a framework for extending PCMs to large data sets comprising microevolutionary data. The methods developed will allow scientists to evaluate the consistency of small-scale and large scale evolutionary relationships in a comparative framework. This project will incorporate both theoretical and empirical components. Statistical research will evaluate the statistical power and inferential error rates of "expanded-PCM" to varied analytical designs, phenotypic variables, tree topologies, and data balance. These methods will be applied empirically to two vertebrate systems to study the phylogenetic relatedness of intra-species morphological variation, as it is associated with intra- and interspecific ecological variation. Several educational outreach activities will also be conducted, including: a research-in-education exchange between a primarily undergraduate university and large research university, and teaching workshops in quantitative methods to train the next generation of students and scientists from around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OUTCOMES

 

Rationale: — How do microevolutionary trends within species translate to macroevolutionary trends across phylogenies?  While this question is at the heart of evolutionary ecology, it remains an analytical paradox to answer.  Phylogenetic comparative methods (PCMs) measure the amount of phylogenetic signal in a set of data or account for the phylogenetic relatedness among observations when evaluating ecological variation, but currently work only with single values for species.  Thus, large amounts of within-species data must be excluded when using PCMs, which limits their inferential capability.  This project sought an analytical solution to this problem, and to provide a framework for extending PCMs to large data sets comprising microevolutionary data.  The methods developed with this award will allow scientists to evaluate the consistency of small-scale and large-scale evolutionary relationships in a comparative framework.

 

Results: — Research on this project resulted in the production of 8 peer-reviewed publications, 6 software programs, 4 conference presentations, and 1 invited talk. Additionally, 3 undergraduate students and 1 graduate student were trained on the project, and the PI taught 5 international workshops which trained 93 scientists from 22 countries.  Data generated from the project will continue to be published for several years.

 

Through this project a series of analytical and statistical tools were developed that further our understanding of the evolution of multivariate phenotypes, and how evolutionary trends of phenotypic diversification progress across the tree of life. The project developed a series of multivariate phylogenetic comparative methods that facilitate the evaluation of macroevolutionary patterns of complex phenotypes. New advances in phylogenetic anova, phylogenetic regression, and phylogenetic ordination, improve our phylogenetic comparative toolkit, with a focus on multivariate applications. In addition, software for permutation-based linear model (RRPP), and methods for evaluating multivariate effect sizes, pave the way for new comparative questions for understanding whether the strength of evolutionary signals are similar (or different) across taxa and traits.

 

Additionally, much morphological data were collected on pupfishes from museum collections, resulting in a Master’s thesis and a database of morphological information to support developing manuscripts for future scientific articles. 

 

Broader Significance and Scientific Importance: — This project provides several analytical advances that have broad application; both in biology, and in other quantitative disciplines. For instance, the analytics underlying RRPP are completely general, and may facilitate analyses of complex datasets in biology, chemistry, psychology, archaeology, and other disciplines with high-dimensional data. Additionally, the algebraic machinery of phylogenetic transformation-based PCMs may be applied to other common sources of non-independence, including spatially and temporally autocorrelated data. Finally, the development of a multivariate effect size, and our approach for their statistical comparison, provides the multivariate equivalent of effect size comparisons in meta-analysis, and may have equally broad appeal and utility across the sciences. Educational Activities: The project has trained three undergraduates and one graduate student directly. Additionally, 93 scholars from 22 countries were trained through five workshops taught by the PI. Societal impact: Empirical results have implications for the conservation of pupfishes, a group of desert fishes that are highly imperiled and currently facing extinction risks.
